cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are expected to leave Port Said on or about the following dates:--
Port-Said to London via Brindisi
The BRINDISI steamer leaves PORT-SAID after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from PORT-SAID to LONDON via BRINDISI or via MARSEILLES £25.9.11
To the East.

The Mail Steamers leave SUEZ for ADEN and BOMBAY every Wednesday, and for AUSTRALIA and CHINA every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for CALCUTTA, fortnightly, and another for JAPAN. Passengers can embark at PORT-SAID.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. Thos, Cook & Son (Egypt) Ltd.… … … … … … … … CAIRO.
George Royle, Esq… … … … … … … … … … … … … … PORT-SAID.
Messrs. Haselden & Co. … … … … … … … … … … … … ALEXANDRIA.
F.G. DAVIDSON, Superintendant P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt. SUEZ. 31-12-90

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste-Venice Line.

Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Alexandria--Patras-Brindisi-Trieste Line.
Stemer leaves Alexandria on or about 9th and 23rd November.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
ALEXANDRIA

A fresh westerly wind, sea prevailed yesterday till 7 p.m. when the wind fell very light and remained almost calm throughout the night, accompanied with the vivd flashes of lightning. Barometer remains steady.

div.head: FORCE APRES MALADIE
div.p: Quand les fievres ou une longue st douloureuse maladie ont reduit le corps a un inquietant etat de faiblesse et d'amaigrissement, un reconstituant qui vous remettra promptement est necesire.
L'EMULSION SCOTT

est le meilleur fortifiant du monde: elle n'a pas d'egale. Elle stimule l'appetit et ameliore promptement la digestion. Elle fait des muscles et enrichit le sang, eile restaure la vitalite et donne a l'organisme le pouvoir de resister a la maladie. L'Emulsion Scott est autant un aliment qu'un remede, car elle fournit au corps affaibli ce dont il a besoin pour reprende muscles et forces: ses nombreux et bien-faisants resultats sont, en verite, supernants. Il y a recilement grand danger a perdre embonpoint et poids; l'organisme, bientot debilite, deviendrait une proie facile pour la maladie.
L'EMULSION SCOTT

contient le principe fortifiant de tous aliments; elle arrete le deperissement et reconstitue une chair saine. Le flacon en est toujours presente dans une enveloppe de papier couleur suamon avec, dessus, cette gravure.
En vente chez tous les pharmaciens et droguistes.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
N.B.– Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1904.

div.head: THE SETTLEMENT OF THE QUESTION.
div.p: The satisfactory alleviation of the terrible state of tension which has prevailed throughout the last week, in consequence of the Baltic Fleet outrage, is a matter for the congratulation to the whole world, and as our telegrams announced yesterday, the Continental Press is unanimous in welcoming the agreement for the settlement of this incident by pacific methods. We in Egypt have also special cause for congratulating ourselves on the happy issue, for there is no doubt that had was ensued between England and Russia the coming season would have been in a great measure ruined. But there are larger and more permanent considerations involved in this submission to peaceful settlement, inasmuch as it acknowledges the power of arbitration to settle international disputes, even when they happen to involve questions of vital interest and national honour. As germane to this subject reference may be made to the important article on the settlement of international differences in the latest Fortnightly Review to hand from the able pen of Sir Thomas Barclay, who has had great practical experience in preparing such treaties. It is to be noted, in the first place, that from treaties of arbitration are excluded matters involving the "vital interests" or "national honour" of either party, which is the exclusion of the very matters which seem the only ones capable of influencing public opinion to a dangerous point. What is a "vital interest?" The independence of a state itself is a vital interest. A deliberate breach in the established usage of nations of fundamental importance might be vital to one state and not to another. "Vital," of course, means something of such gravity that it cannot be settled by an award of damages, in which, in other words, there is no solution but reversion to the status quo ante. "National honour" is very like a "vital interest" but it generally arises out of the overheated discussion of some questions which was originally a judicial one. Every question can become one of national honour in the hands of an unskilled diplomacy, and very often what is called national honour is merely the outcome of a one-sided view of a question in which honour plays a very little part. On the other hand, does it much detract from the value of these new treaties that there is a loophole offered by which either nation can escape in an emergency from its obligations? Treaties between nations cannot be viewed exactly in the same light as contracts between individuals. The best we can offer as their sanction is the sense of honour and justice between the contracting parties, and it will always be better to escape from a treaty through its own provisions than by violating them. Peaceable adjustment of differences in the dealings of nations with each other has been the dream of every enlightened man who ever thought upon the subject. The Alabama case, the establishment of a Permanent Court of Judicature at The Hague, and the new obilgation entered into by Great Britain and France, so rapidly followed by others, to submit all their differences of a judicial order to The Hague Tribunal, are the three events which stand out as landmarks of progress towards that ideal.

Crtics of these treaties have not understood what the practical effect of an obligatory treaty of arbitration is. They view a treaty of arbitration in the light of a restraint placed upon the contracting Governments. They assume that Governments are bloodthirsty ogres only too anxious to plunge their countries into fire and blooshed, and that a muzzle has to be put upon them and that they only yeild to pressure and negociate such treaties with reluctance. It is indeed a grave mistake to think that democratic Governments, at the present day, can afford to view arbitration with distrust. Foreign offices and diplomatists may have misgivings about details, even very essential details, but they can have little objection to pacific methods of any kind for the settlement of international differences as they can have to the whole protocol system of diplomacy. Diplomacy has no raison d'etre but that it is itself a pacific method, and its history has been one of constantly adding of varieties to its provision of devices for keeping a question open. A permanent treaty of arbitration is an additional device in the hands of diplomacy for this purpose. It is not a shackle impeding the free activity of the diplomatist, but an instrument in his hands by which ha can make another last endeavour to settle any difficulty when all his other instruments have proved unavailing. It is usual to speak of arbitration as applicable "when diplomacy has failed," as in the Hague Peace Convention, the treaty of 1897, etc., but it is evident that diplomacy must be the medium of negotiation for this further stage in pacific efforts. The de facto position "when diplomacy ahs failed," is that the diplomatist is recalled by his Government, and there is then little hope of peace but in the mediation of an independent Government and its acceptance by the two parties. With a permanent treaty of arbitration in existence between the two parties, the danger of such a breakdown is, at any rate, poatponed. The diplomatist is not recalled. The only difference is that negotiations are turned into a new channel, in accordance with the terms of the treaty. Under the provisions of these new treaties there will be a number of questions for diplomacy to settle. First of all, there is the question of whether any "vital interest" or "national honour" is involved, and if not, and the question is determined be judicial order, the exact subject of dispute will have to be settled – that is to say, the subject will have to be narrowed down to a precise issue, and even then the powers of the arbitrators and the details of procedure will have to be fixed. All this means machinery at the disposal of the diplomatist. When in 1856 the Treaty of Paris was under discussion, Mr. Gladstone said, "No country ought to resort to arbitration until it had reduced its claims to that

condition in which they were fit to be supported y force." It will be for the diplomatists under these treaties to reduce the respective claims of their Governments to the minimum, to bring them down to the essential point of points beyond which neither Government will give way. In many cases, probably this whittling process will suggest solution, as in private litigation, and they will be "settled out of court."

On the other hand, it would be mere optimism to think the diplomatist in this further stage of negotiations will always be successful. There are diplomatists of the "new school," who like to carry on their business in the broad light of day, and think the hand-claps of an audience help them to their task. There are others – and thank goodness they are the majority – who prefer the more noble and, as history has proved, more successful methods by which diplomacy has earned an honourable and a commendable meaning. Lord Dufferin once observed that war, in his opinion, was generally an accident of diplomacy. To avoid such accidents, men trained in the courtesy of nations, and gifted with the necessary graces of mind and manner, and with resourcefulness – the most essential quality of the diplomatists – should of course be selected to fill, at any rate, the more delicate positions. Mistakes inherent to things human can be laid to the charge of most Governments in their choice of representatives; one of the advantages of permanent treaties of arbitration will be to make errors remediable. It is not, by the way, without its lesson that the United States Governments select their diplomatic representatives from among men of the whole party who seem to the President, by their natural gifts and character, and experience and knowledge of their country's practical affairs, best adapted for each responsible post. It is certain that the United States have not been able, in spite of certain shortcomings, through their diplomatic representatives, to make friends for their country all over the world. The best engine can be driven inefficiently. The Anglo-French Treaty, in the hands of a skilled driver, is quite a storehouse of resources for the prolongation of negotitations. We may assume that when a difficulty arises the object of the one or the other Government will be from the very first peace or war. If it be peace, they will have ample means of removing the subject from the danger of acute public contoversy. National passions, like most other nervous maladies, are generally curable if left to the benign influence of time. To gain time in an emergency is generally the difficulty. The Anglo-French Treaty will certainly enable the Governemnts, if they wish to profit by it, to gain all the time they want. The employment of paicifc methods in arranging international difficulties in a commanding event in the history of the progress of civilisation, and is one of the greatest works with which statesmen can couple their names. "The greatest of British interests is peace." At any rate, it is a "vital interest" of the democratic elements of every nation, and the satisfactory solution of last week's incident, whereby a Russian Trafalgar has been averted, should be acclaimed by all who have the interests of international comity at heart. Just as England was the pioneer of civilisation in her efforts to suppress the slave trade, so here again she will be found in the vanguard of nations desirous of maintaining the world's peace, and the entire civilised world should be grateful from draing the sword when our national honour and sense of humanity had been so deeply wounded by the piratical escapades of the Baltic fleet.

General Kuropatkin reports that the Japanese have begun a significant movement by concentrating eastwards. They are receiving reinforcements, evidently preparatory to assuming the offensive. (Reuter.)
A telegram yesterday from General Kuropatkin states the Japanese have begun to take the offensive.
Admiral Alexeieff has left for Russia. (H.)
The Diet will meet on the 25th November in order to discuss the Budget, which will double the Income Tax and augment other taxes for the purpose of meeting the war expenditure. (Reuter.)
General Linievitch has been appointed to command the first Manchurian Army. (R.)

div.head: BECK & CO'S PILSENER BEER
div.p: BREMEN.
THE WORLD-WIDE KNOWN THE BEST.
Obtainable from every Respectable Firm In Cairo, Alexandria & the Sudan.
Otherwise apply to
V. J. FLEURENT, Cairo
F. MICALLEF, Sole Agent, 11 Bab Midan, Alexandria

div.head: PORT ARTHUR.
div.p: VIGOROUS FIGHTING.
TWO POSITIONS CAPTURED.
CHI-FU, October 31.
The general attack on Port Arthur is proceeding with unabated vigour. The Japanese have captured two positions. (R.)
CHI-FU, October 31.
The battle was still raging at Port Arthur yesterday. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: OPENING OF RUSSIAN ENQUIRY.
ANGLO-RUSSIAN CONVENTION
VIGO, October 31.
The Russian enquiry opened yesterday. (Reuter.)
TANGIER, October 31.
Five Russian destroyers have left. The remainder of the fleet is coaling and provisioning.
Rear-Admiral Bridgeman, from Gibraltar, has visited the British Legation. (Reuter.)
LONDON, October 31.
Great Britain and Russia are negotiating a special convention for the appointment of a commision of enquiry. The latter will probably meet at Cherbourg. (Reuter.)
END OF MOBILISATION MANEUVRES.
GIBRALTAR, October 31.
The mobilisation maneuvres ended yesterday. (Reuter.)
BRITISH TROOPSHIP ESCORTED.
GIBRALTAR, October 31.
The troopship Assaye was detained here, but has since proceeded escort by H.M.S. Illustrious. (Reuter.)

div.head: SERVIA AND ROMANIA.
div.p: ENTENTE BETWEEN THE COUNTRIES.
SOFIA, October 31.

King Peter is visiting Prince Ferdinand. The ceremonies include the singing of a Te Deum. At a banquet given this evening at the Russian Agency, Prince Ferdinand and King Peter drank the most cordial toasts, declaring that the present conditions imposed a close entente between the two countries.
The Macedonians published a protest asserting that the object of the entente is the partition of Macedonia.
The British Agent was absent from all the ceremonies. (Reuter.)
SOFIA, October 31.
The King of Servia has been paying a visit to Prince Ferdinand. They exchanged toasts to the fraternity of the two peoples. (Havas.)

div.head: DEATH OF DAN LENO.
div.p: LONDON, October 31.
Dan Leno is dead. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE NEW STATION
div.p: at Koubbeh has been completed at a total cost of L.E. 1,500.

div.head: KING'S BIRTHDAY.
div.p: – On the 9th inst., being the King's Birthday, the Gouvernorats with all the consulates and agencies will have their flags flying.

div.head: RECEPTION.
div.p: – On Friday, 11inst., Count Arrivabence Gonzaga will hold a reception at the Italian Agency in honour of the birthday of H.M. the King of Italy.

div.head: ARABIC MUSEUM.
div.p: – From to-day up to April 31, the Museum of Arab Art, in Cairo, will open daily, except on Fridays and public holidays, from 9 a.m. to 4.30 p.m.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL ROADS.
div.p: – Mr. N. Zagoras has been appointed engineer in charge of the construction of the projected agricultural roads in the province of Assiout, at L.E. 27 ½ per mensem.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: – On the 28th ult., 10 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 8 were British, 1 German, and 1 French. The transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 346 vessels amounted to 9,162,669.48 frs.

div.head: EXIT THE "PATRIOT."
div.p: – The rumor is gaining ground in native circles that, as a result of his recent letter to the Khedive, Mustapha Pasha Kamel will be exiled from the country. Apropos of this rumor, the Wattan says that if the worthy "patriot" is not exiled from the country he is at any rate exiled from the hearts of the Egyptians.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive will leave Alexandria on Tuesday next by special train from Montazah at 7.30 a.m., and will arrive at Cairo at 11.30 a.m., proceeding direct to Abdeen Palace.
H.H. the Khedivah and children will leave Montazah Palace at 7.40 a.m. on the same day and will arrive at the new Koubbeh station at 12.20 p.m. Her Highness will stay at Koubbeh Palace.

On the occasion of his approaching departure for Cairo, the Khedive will hold a reception at Ras-el-Tin Palace on Saturday next. The order in which the reception will be held will appear in to-morrow's issue.

div.head: THE MINISTERS.
div.p: The Ministers will leave Cairo for Alexandria on the 5th inst., and will remain here till the 8th, when they accompany the Khedive to Cairo.

div.head: VISIT OF PRINCE LEOPOLD.
div.p: H.H. Prince Leopold of Battenberg, who is to spend the winter in Egypt, will be arriving in Cairo about the middle of December. A Suite of apartments has been taken for his Highness at the Hotel d'Angleterre.

div.head: VISIT OF BISHOP OF GIBRALTAR.
div.p: The Bishop of Gibraltar and Mrs. Collins are expected to pay a visit to Alexandria shortly, on the conclusion of their visit to Constantinople.

div.head: FINANCE MINISTRY.
div.p: An arrete of the above Ministry states that Mr. Mitchell Innes, Unit Secretary of State for this department, will be replaced on the special council of discipline during his absence on leave by Ibrahim Pasha Neguib, Under-Secretart of State for the Ministry of the Interior.

div.head: NEW ASSIZE COURTS.
div.p: A series of meetings ahs been held by the Committee of the Legislative Council under the presidency of Sheikh Mohamned Abdou. The Judicial Adviser, Mr. Bond, Vice-President of the Native Court of Appeal, Mr. Brunyate, the Chef des Contentieux de l'Etat, and Abdel Khalek Bey Sarwat were present and took part in the discussion of the question of the new Assize Courts.

div.head: MIXED COURTS.
div.p: The magistrates of the Alexandria Mixed Tribunal of 1st Instance held a meeting yesterday afternoon and re-elected Judge Ernest Eeman as president of the Tribunal. M.B. de Zoltan was elected vice-president and president of the Commercial Chamber, in place of M.F. Rauret, Spanish judge, who has resigned. The new vice-president has only been in Egypt for three years.

div.head: MINISTRY OF THE INTERIOR.
div.p: Bimbashi Martin, formerly inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, has now replaced Bewley Bey as director of stores at Boulac.
Kaimakam Paterson Bey, Assitant Commandent of Police, Cairo, has been transferred to the Ministry of the Interior.
It has not yet been decided who will take Paterson Bey's place.
Kaimakam Melville, late Commandnat of the Port Said Police, has commenced his new duties at the Ministry of the Interior as sub-inspector.
Schalch Bey, the newly-appointed Commandant of the Port Said Police, in place of Kaimakam Melville, has been granted the rank of Miralai.

div.head: GREAT IMPROVEMENTS AT CAIRO.
div.p: It is stated that on the completion of the filling in of the land between the Pont des Auglais and the Cafe des Tramways on the Ghizeh road, a promenade will be constructed along the Nile bank from ten to fifteen metres in width.

div.head: WORKMEN'S DWELLINGS.
div.p: At to-morrow's meeting of the Municipal Commision an application made by the Tenants Commission, asking the Municipal Commission to guarantee the interest of 4% or to undertake the issue of a special loan for building workmen's dwellings, will be discussed.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE.
div.p: An excellent performance of Les Deux Gosses (Two Little Vagabonds) was given last night by the French comedy company, whose successful season st this theatre draws to a close this week.
The Castellano Italian opera company is to pay a return visit to the Alhambra on the conclusion of its Cairo engagement.

div.head: NIAM-NIAM.
div.p: – Names of African tribes are generally a puzzle to the uninitiated, but few would suspect the origin of "Niam-Niam" – the name of the tribe to whose country the Sudan Government is said to be sending an expedition. It is not the designation by which the people call themselves, which is A-Zandeh. The A-Zandeh are noted for their intelligance and for a degree of culture considerably in advance of neighbouring tribes; they are also noted for their cannibal proclivities, and it is credibly stated – by travellers such as Schweinfurth – that "Niam-Niam" is nothing more than the nickname bestowed by the Arabs in imitation of the sound made by the A-Zandeh when enjoying one of their cannibal feasts. It is to the Arabs, by the way, that we owe the common word Kaffir – i.e., and unbeliever in Mohamed.

div.head: NIAM-NIAM EXPEDITION.
div.p: UNFOUNDED REPORTS.
A number of our English contemporaries published the following telegram from Cairo last week:–

"The expedition to the Niam-Niam country has now been definitely decided upon, and, as already stated, it will be composed of about two thousend Sudanese troops under British officers. The base of the expedition will be Wao, in the Bahr-el-Ghazal. Stores are now being rapidly accumulated there. It is hoped to make a start some time in December. It is now believed the Niam-Niams have a force of fully 15,000 fighting men.

"Major Boulnois, R.A., of the Egyptian Army, will take command of the expedition. His force will consist of a company of Mounted Infantry, the 9th and the 10th Sudanese battalions, and half of the 15th battalion, with Maxims.

"It will be remembered that in February of this year Major Boulnois, with a force of about 1,000 men, attempted to reach the Niam-Niam country, but in view of the threatening attitude of the inhabitants and the smallness of his force he was compelled to retire. The Niam-Niams are a vigorous Sudanese race, very jealous of their independence, and likely to resent any attempt on the part of the Government of the Sudan to enter into relations with them. They have Remington rifles, and also use bows and poisoned arrows. The country is most difficult, being covered with long grass, and the paths which intersect it are so narrow that it is only possible to march in a single file. Water, however, is said to be plentiful."

We can only say that the above statements are greatly exaggerated. On enquiry at official sources we learn that there is no question of a campaign against the whole of the Niam-Niam tribe. The above story probably originated from the fact that the Sirdar and Major Boulnois are going shortly on an inspection of the Bahr-el-Ghazal garrison, and Yambio, gave some trouble to the authorities a few months ago.

div.head: SIRDAR AT ASSOUAN.
div.p: Assouan, Monday.– The Sirdar, H.E. Sir R. Wingate Pasha, arrived here at midday to-day by boat from Luxor and left again for Halfa at one o'clock. Lady Wingate remains in Cairo for another 15 days. (Our Correspondent.)

div.head: EGYPTIAN NITRATES AND PHOSPHATES SYNDICATE.
div.p: The development of the syndicate for exploiting the concession, recently granted by the Egyptian Government, for the purpose of providing manures, is proceeding apace. An engineer from England has recently been inspecting the syndicate's concession near Esneh, and plans have been made for laying down the necessary material. The machinery will be shipped from England in a few months time, and the railway plant for taking the nitrates from the desert to the river bank is already on its way from Alexandria. The concession is situated in the districts of Esneh and Coptos.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINIG.
div.p: Mr. A.P. Mack, managing director of the Nile Valley Co., writes from Um Garaiart:– May I call your attention to an error which appears in the paragraph headed "Mining Expedition" in your paper under date of 20th inst. I did not join Mr. Wells as a leader in his expedition, neither was the expedition intended to demonstrate the validity of my company's claims. Mr. Wells informed me, on my arrival in Egypt early in Spetember, that he was passing through my company's territory on his way South and East, and would halt at Um Garaiart to rest and water his camels, and I took the opportunity of riding with him from Assouan to Um Garaiart, where I have since remained.

div.head: MOTOR TRACTION FOR CAIRO.
div.p: An application has been addressed to the Ministry of Public Works for permission to institute a service of motor wagons for the transport of sand and stones from the quarries in the neighbourhood of the Capital. Messrs. Theocaridis and Adamidis, of Alexandria, are the applicants.

While the question of motor wagons is under consideration, it is worth while asking why some energetic capitalist does not also apply for a permit to work motor 'buses in Cairo. The present 'buses are eyesores as vehicles, cumbersome in construction, constantly obstructing traffic, and far too heavy for the miserable quadrupeds which have to draw them. We understand that the Omnibus Company is composed of some of the most influential capitalists in Cairo and it returns a substantial dividend of, so rumor hath it, about 80 per cent. per annum. A 4 share in this company is now worth 20, so there should be every chance for successfully launching a motor omnibus company, as there are many streets in Cairo, especially in the native quarters, which can never be tapped by the Tramway Company. Moreover, many of the narrow streets in the native quarters, where a small motor 'bus carrying sixteen passengers could circulate, would not be available for the cumberous omnibuses now in vogue.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Khedivial S.S. Minish will leave Alexandria on Saturday and Port Said on Sunday for Beyrout, Tripoli, Mereins, Alexandretta, Caiffa, ad Jaffa.
The S.S. Sardinia, of the Papayanni Line, left Liverpool yesterday afternoon and is expected to arrive at this port on the 15th inst.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN ADVENTURER
div.p: HIS EXPLOITS IN PARIS.
A Paris corespondent writes under date of the 23rd inst:–

An Egyptian adventurer, who gave himself out as Prince George, and is said to be the son of a Cairo diamond merchant, has been tried and convicted for swindling Paris jewellers and dealers in precious stones. This man, who lived in a garret of the slums, was able by his representation to obtain on credit rubies, diamonds, pearls, and sapphires from nearly a dozen dealers. From one jeweller alone he had goods worth 2,000. The sham prince was well known in the world of amusement. He associated with actresses, variety artists, circus riders, tight-rope dancers, and several demi-mondaines, including Blondinette Daleza, who was brought forward prominently in the romance of the phantom millions as the friend of Romain Daurignac, Madame Humbert's gay brother. Mdlle. Daleza, who has appeared occasionally on the stage, was called as a witness yesterday in the Ninth Correctional Chamber, where "Prince George," the Egyptian, was tried. She said that she knew the prince cheifly through his little friend, Madame Karat, of the Marigny Theatre. George was presented to Mdlle. Daleza at the Cascade Restaurant in the Peir de Boulogne, and she subsequently saw him waiting for Madame Karat at the Marigny rehearsals. One day George put two valuable rings on Madame Karat's fingers. "Did he ever put any on yours?" queried the President of the Court. "No," said Blondinette, "he never gave me anything. A few days ago he came to me, and asked me to tell his little friend Karat that he was called away suddenly to Brussels." Also, in answer to the President, Mdlle. Daleza said that George spent a lot of money, and lived like a man who had 12,000 a year. He hired a carriage and pair for Karat, and had for himself a luxurious motor-car of the most modern make. The Egyptian was sentenced to imprisonment for two years and a fine of 20, this being the maximum penalty in his case.

div.head: COQUELIN AINE AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: We give below the complete programme of the performances to be given at the Zizinia Theatre by Coquelin Aine and his company:–
Friday, 4th November.– Tartufe, comedy in 5 acts by Moliere.– Les Precieuses Ridicules, comedy in 1 act by Moliere.
Saturday, 5th.– L'Abbe Constantin, comedy in 3 acts by Ludovic Halevy and P. Decourcelle.– Monologues given by M. Coquelin Aine.
Sunday, 6th.– 3rd and 5th Acts of Cyrano de bergerac, a heroic-comic play by M. Ed. Rostand.– Le Ceur a ses raisons, comedy in 1 act by Messrs, de Caillavet and de Flers.
Monday, 7th.– Le Gendre de M. Poirier, comedy in 4 acts by Messrs. Emile Augier and Jules Sandeau.– Monologues given by M. Coquelin Aine.– Le Depit Amoureux, comedy in 2 acts by Moliere.
Tuesday, 8th.– Le Depute de Bombignac, comedy in 3 acts by M. A. Bisson, and La Joie fait peur, comedy in 1 act by M. Emile de Girardin.
Wednesday, 9th.– L'aventuriere, comedy in 4 acts by E. Augier.– Gringoire, comedy in 1 act by M. Th. de Banville.
Subscribers for the series of performances are requested to withdraw their coupons from Zoller's Bookstall, Cherif Pasha-street.

div.head: PASSENGER LISTS.
div.p: ARRIVALS.
Le paquebot Ismailia, de la Cie Khediviale arrive hier de Constantinople, Metelin, Smyrne et Piree, avait a bord:

S.A. la Princesse Said Pacha Halim et suite de 32 personnes, S.E. et Mme Mohamed Bey Moustafa, M. et Mme Panayotti Theokarides et famille, Dr. et Mme Iakvorian et famille, M. et Mme Abdul Hamid Effendi El Samadani, M. et Mme Zalichis et famille, M. et Mme Kerantem, M. et Mme De Saumarez, M. et Mme Nicoletopulos, M. et Mme A. Pangalos et suite, M. et Mme Patouna et famille, M. et Mme Toitoulis' M. Le Baron de Belov, M.M. Calvocoressi, Nomicos, J. Kazacos, O. Majoratti, T. Nicolopoulo, J. Tasarti, S. Menaim, N. Lely, Angelopoullo, Mme Nestoros, M. et Mme Theodore Zelendis et famille, M. Tricardo et sa soeur, Mmes Nattalia Nicolai et Sarah, Moissesso, M.A. Hardnt, M. Haritakis, Jean Pesmazoglu, N. Casanera, Mmes Ibrahim Effendi et Tewfik Bey, N. Vergopoulo, N.J. Manusso, Nicola Tassopoulo, Madame Sevastopoulo, M. et Madame A.S. Baltazzi, Stephan Sivrissarian, Nicolas Kyriakidis, M. Stockter, Elie Hazan, Mmes Albagli et Haydn, Anas Vola, Madame Batazzi et sa soeur, P. Mandras, P. Leondi, M. Codonis, C. Condouras, M. Triandafilidis, S. Papageorgiou, Jean Caratza, Siami Bey, Emin bey Hussein, M. et Mme David Mazar et famille, Mme A. Sakakini Agha, Ismail Eff. Ahmed, Maria Valianos, Chemsigull, Hannoun, Caravia, Altimoff, mme E. Luzzati, Mme D. Luzzati, Mislimedjan, Kadin, Mohamed Bey Cherif, Feride Hanem, M. Groner, Jule Cherdiac, Madame Theofanos, J. Papoulpoulos, Michel Riga, 48 pelerins et 152 passagers de pont.

div.head: ALAS, POOR MAHDI:–
div.p: It is reported from Berber that a new Mahdi, named Abou Zeid Mohamed Farah, of the Chanatir tribe, has arisen there. The Moudir, in presence of the supporters of his divine mission, stated, after a medical examination, that the man was suffering from religious mania, and so the false Mahdi has been imrisoned.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Princess Said Pasha Halim arrived at Alexandria to-day from Constantinople by the S.S. Ismailia.
The Maharajah of Jhalawar visited the tombs of the Khalifs, the Pyramids, and Sakharh on Saturday and Sunday.
Judge and Mrs. Saumarez arrived from Constantinople to-day.
Mr. J. Currie, Director of Education under the Sudan Government, wil return to Khartoum this week.
Sayed Bey Zaglool, Judge at the Native Court of Appeal, arrived yesterday afternoon from Cairo.

Mr. Leigh Hunt arrived at Shepheard's Hotel yesterday afternoon. He intends to stay in Cairo for about ten days and will then go up to Berber, where he is building a house. He intends to make his headquarters in the Sudan there.

Mr. and Mrs. E.V. Bird, the well-known Bostonians, who come to Egypt every winter, arrived at Shepheard's Hotel yesterday afternoon and intend staying in Cairo for a fortnight. Their dahabeah is being got ready for them, and they intend spending all the winter months on the Nile.

Mr. Basset, the well-known Boston banker, and his wife are staying at Shepheard's Hotel. They are on a tour round the world, but before they leave Egypt they are going up the Nile and leave Cairo by Cook's steamer on November 15. They are returning to Cairo in December and depart about the middle of that month for India.

Among the visitors at present staying at Shepheard's Hotel are Prince A. Colonna, from Rome, D. Mouheb Bey, Moudir of the Fayoum, Mrs. M. van Buren, Mr. J.V. Strawson, from Rome, Mr. Haynes, Mr. Frayley, the well-known American actor, who is on his way home from Cape Town, Mr. and Mrs. Rickehaus, Mrs. Oetker, from Germany, Mr. and Mrs. Weber, from Russia, Mrs. Hutchinson, From London, the Rev. and Mrs. Dillon Bronson, Mr. Friedlaender, from New York, and Dr. Brabent, from London, etc.
Dr. Tannicliffe, the well-known London physician of Harley-street, is due at Shepheard's Hotel on the 8th inst.

We regret to learn of the death, which took place at Paris yesterday morning, at the early age of 17, of Miss Mary Sursock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Sursock, to whom we tender our sincere condolences in their cruel bereavement.

There has been a general desire on the part of the employes of the Post Office Administration to subscribe towrads a magnificent present for the daughter of the Postmaster-General, Miss Mary Saba, on the occasion of her marriage with Nahas Bey, which will take place on the 19th November. Saba Pasha has, however, expressed a wish that the employes of the administration, of which he is the chief, ahould not subscribe towards any present.
Mr. W.R. Williams, Inspector of Irrigation, 3rd Circle, returned from leave on Saturday.

We hear that Dr. Bentley has removed his consulting-rooms from the Tewfik Palace Hotel to the town of Helouan, where he has taken the villa "Mena," at which address he will reside this winter when in Helouan.

The well-known Mr. C. Aquilina, late of Messrs. Cook & Son and proprietor of the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley, has returned to Helouan and resumed the management of the Tewfik Palace Hotel, which opens to-day.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demi)

Bien que le marche de Londres soit en hausse et tre anime – la Banque Nationale y est cotee 23 ¾ et l'Agricole 11 3/8 – ici la situation reste sans entrain par suite d'une tendance generale a realiser.

Les cours cependant se maintiennent et nombre de valeurs sont meme en hausse sensible: Ainsi l'Agricole atteint 10 15/16, la Banque Nationale 23 5/16, la Behera 53 ½, la Delta Land 3 1/8, la Daira 21 9/16, la Salt & Soda 27/3, et la Delta Light 15 ½.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea Central Position. Under English management.

div.head: HOTEL BEAU-RIVAGE, RAMLEH.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in the finest part of Ramleh, close to Halte Laurans (Station after S. Stefano). Magnificent sea view. Prommade on shore. Sea Bath. Restaurant. Buffet. Splendid Garden. Electric Light. Moderate charges. Special terms.
Mrs. LUIGI STEINSCHNEIDER, Proprietor.
Telegraph Address: "Beuarivage," Telephone No. 185.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL,
div.p: CAIRO
NOTED FOR ITS EXCELLENT CUISINE.
ELECTRIC LIGHT. LIFT.
Special terms for officers of the Army of Occupation and Government Officials. 26-11-90
